description: From Middle English religioun, from Old French religion, from Latin religiō (“scrupulousness, pious misgivings, superstition, conscientiousness, sanctity, an object of veneration, cult-observance, reverence”). Most likely from the Proto-Indo-European *h₂leg- with the meanings preserved in Latin dīligere and legere (“to read repeatedly”, “to have something solely in mind”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Belief in a spiritual or metaphysical reality (often including at least one deity), accompanied by practices or rituals pertaining to the belief.
examples: My brother tends to value religion, but my sister not as much.

entries.meaning: (countable) A particular system of such belief, and the rituals and practices proper to it.
(uncountable) The way of life committed to by monks and nuns.
examples: The monk entered religion when he was 20 years of age.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, informal) Rituals and actions associated with religious beliefs, but considered apart from them.
examples: I think some Christians would love Jesus more if they weren't so stuck in religion.
Jack's spiritual, but he's not really into religion.

entries.meaning: (countable) Any practice to which someone or some group is seriously devoted.
examples: At this point, Star Trek has really become a religion.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, obsolete) Faithfulness to a given principle; conscientiousness. [16th–17th c.]

verbs.description: religion (third-person singular simple present religions, present participle religioning, simple past and past participle religioned)

examples: To men whose minds are thus religioned, tied back to gods that never advance, there can never be any such word as progress

entries.meaning: To make sacred or symbolic; sanctify.
examples: The ideas expressed above challenge us to continuously rupture and interrupt racialized, classed, gendered, religioned and sexualized norms that inhere between and within institutions, understandings of bodies and our Selves.
